PDx:[[oc1:: IBD, most probably Ulcerative Colitis]]

DDx:
  • Other IBD - [[oc2::Crohn's disease]]
  • Infectious - [[oc3::Gastroenteritis (Camp., Shigella, C. Diff)]]
  • Malabsorptive - [[oc4::Coeliac disease]]
  • Medications - [[oc5::Pseudomembranous colitis, laxatives]]
  • Others, especially when older - [[oc6::Ischaemic colitis, malignancy, diverticulitis, bleeding disorder]]

State your PDx and DDx
43yo F, presents with 2wk Hx of bloody diarrhoea, 12x in last 10hrs. Pain in L and R upper quadrants, previous episode 2yrs ago that resolved.

  • Malabsorptive - {{c21::Coeliac disease}}
  • Medications - {{c21::Pseudomembranous colitis, laxatives}}
  • Others, especially when older - {{c21::Ischaemic colitis, malignancy, diverticulitis, bleeding disorder}}

History: 
  • [[oc1::Characterise pain and diarrhoea. 
  • Ask about extraintestinal IBD Sx (joints, eyes, skin)
  • Constitutional and infective Sx
  • PMHx, Meds, FHx, travel Hx
  • Smoking/drugs/ETOH
    • ]]
Examination:
  • [[oc5::
  • Clubbing
  • Anaemia (pallor, stomatitis, sinus tachy)
  • Abdominal palpation (tenderness, masses)
  • DRE – peri-anal disease (UC), mass, fissure, haemorrhoid, frank blood
  • Extra-intestinal examination (eyes – uveitis, joints – sacroillitis, skin – pyoderma gangrenosum, erythema nodosum
    • ]]
Bedside:
  • [[oc2::Stool MCS, OPS (ova, parasites, spores)
  • C. Diff toxin test (TcdA/TcdB)
    • ]]
Bloods:
  • [[oc3::FBC (Fe anaemia), ESR/CRP
  • LFT (liver issues, pri sclerosing cholangitis)
  • EUC/CMP (electrolyte disturbances, dehydration)
  • ANCA/ASCA (p-ANCA +ve in 70% of UC)
  • Blood cultures (sepsis)
    • ]]
Imaging:
  • [[oc4::Colonoscopy + biopsy (contraindicated with toxic megacolon)
  • AXR or CT Abdo (if suspect perforation or toxic megacolon - >6cm diameter)
    • UC - loss of haustra, granular mucosa, shortened colon
    • Crohn's - cobblestoning, "rose thorn" ulcers, colon strictures w/ rectal sparing
    ]]
Other:
  • TFT (hyperthyroid = non-bloody diarrhoea)
  • Transglutaminase Ab test + Anti-endomysial Ab (IgA type) = Coeliac disease
  • FOBT 
  • PCR (?virus)

What are the categories of complications of UC?

Intestinal (acute, chronic)

Extra-intestinal (eyes, skin, joints, haem, hepatobill, bones, dehydration, nails)
What are the acute complications of UC?

• Perforation +/- peritonitis
  • Bleeding (from erosion of an artery, rare, but life threatening)
  • Toxic megacolon +/- rupture
What are the chronic complications of UC?

• Colonic adenocarcinoma (CRC)
  • Perianal abscess
  • Fistula (more likely with Crohn's due to transmural inflammation)
  • Strictures
  • amyloidosis

Symptomatic relief: 
  • [[oc1::Antidiarrheal agents: loperamide
  • Anticholinergic medication: propantheline, dicyclomine
    • ]]
Acute: [[oc2::using 5-aminosalicylic acid derivatives (5-ASAs) 
rectal → +oral → +oral corticosteroids → alternatives and biologicals
]] 

Maintainence: [[oc3::Oral/rectal 5-ASA → both → alternatives]]

5-ASAs ([[oc1::5-Animosalicylic acid derivatives]]):
  • [[oc2::Mesalamine]]
  • [[oc2::Sulfasalazine]]
  • [[oc2::Olsalazine]]
Mild: [[oc3::5-ASA as suppository or enema, topical steroid (budesonide) if not tolerated]]

Moderate: [[oc4::Oral + topical 5-ASAs, can use in combination with topical budesonide]]

Severe: [[oc5::High dose oral + topical 5-ASA and Oral corticosteroids.
if insufficient: IV corticosteroids]]

Steroid-refractory Disease: 
  • [[oc6::

    • Surgery (curative! proctocolectomy)
    Alternatives: infliximab, tacrolimus
    ]]

1st line (dec. risk of colon cancer)
  • [[oc1::mild: oral/rectal 5-ASA]]
  • [[oc1::mod-severe: oral + rectal 5-ASA]]
  • [[oc1::5-ASA intolerance: probiotics (E Coli strain Nissle 1917)]]
Alternatives:
  • [[oc2::Azathioprine/6-mercaptopurine]]
  • [[oc2::Infliximab]] 
Surgery:[[oc3::
  • curative, reduces risk of colon cancer
  • indicated if acute complications, severe relapses, long term dependance on steroids
  • Proctocolectomy
  • can be cured surgically, unlike Crohn's 
]]

General
  • [[oc1::nicotine]] abstinence
  • lactose intolerance - [[oc2::lactose-free diet]]
  • appropriate [[oc3::nutrion]] supplementation
  • bile acid diarrhoea - [[oc4::give ion-exchange resins to bind bile acids (eg. cholestyramine) to reduce osmotic diarhhoea (risk of steatorrhoea)]]
  • During acute episodes: [[oc5::avoid dietary fibre, consider parenteral nutrition]]

Pharmacotherapy
  • [[oc6::step up or step down therapy (weak to strong, or strong to weak meds)]]
Surgery
  • [[oc7::
  • if medical therapy fails, or complications (obstruction, fistula, stricture)
  • non-curative, last resort
  • resection of affected bowel
    • ]]
Prevention
  • [[oc8::
  • regular check ups
  • Smoking cessation
  • prophylactic Abx, 5-ASAs, etc
    • ]]

55M, 2hr hx of central, retrosternal, crushing chest pain on exertion.
What are his cardiac risk factors?

1. [[oc1::Hand hygiene (moment 1), check patient ID, informed consent, ensure appropriate hx and tests on blood culture request form]]
  2. [[oc2::Collect equipment (including personal protection equipment) and place on a trolley cleaned with alcohol-based wipes. Sterile gloves, small dressing pack, cotton balls, tape, tourniquet(s). Two blood culture sets (4 bottles) comprising two aerobic and two anaerobic bottles. Check expiry date for each bottle and mark 10mL above the broth for fill level.]]
  3. [[oc4::Chlorhexidine gluconate (> 0.5%) with 70% alcohol solution, opened onto the sterile field. Vacutainer and leash with winged infusion set designed to fit over the blood culture bottle (or syringe with appropriate blood transfer to vacutainer) ]]
  4. [[oc5::Remove the cap of each blood culture bottle and using a non-touch technique scrub the vial stoppers well using a fresh chlorhexidine and 70% alcohol swab and allow to dry for 30 seconds]]
  5. [[oc6::Prep and position patient appropriately, apply tourniquet to palpate and identify appropriate vein. Hand hygiene (Moment 2),  put on sterile gloves, sterilise site (dry = 30s).]] 
  6. [[oc7::Perform venepuncture using vacutainer and leash with winged infusion set/luer adapter (release tourniquet during procedure where appropriate, this will contaminate the gloved hand and using a sterile towel or the non-dominant hand is advised)]]
  7. [[oc8::Place 10mL blood per bottle (20mL/set, 40mL in total), keeping blood culture bottle upright and at/below the level of the venepuncture. Always collect/innoculate the blood culture bottles FIRST (innoculating the aerobic bottle first) then, if required, collect additional blood pathology tubes at this point]]
  8. [[oc9::Apply cotton ball and pressure to site (where possible obtain patient assistance to hold and apply pressure); repeat procedure for 2nd set of blood cultures at a different peripheral site, maintaining aseptic technique, invert bottles gently several times to prevent clotting ]]
  9. [[oc10::Discard sharps, collect all rubbish/dirty items and dispose appropriately. Label each bottle with patient name, MRN, date/time for collection of blood and location of site used for each set. Do not cover any bar codes or the bottom of the bottle and place bottles into biohazard bag and arrange to send to the lab with request form, transport bottles at room temperature. Remove gloves and perform hand hygiene – (Moment 3, after the procedure). Inform px. Results not available for 48hrs]]
  10. [[oc12::Document that (a) two sets of blood cultures have been taken, (b) from which sites, (c) include reason for site choice if this differs from a peripheral site. Do not delay administering antibiotics, do not wait for results]]

  3. Chlorhexidine gluconate (> 0.5%) with 70% alcohol solution, opened onto the sterile field. Vacutainer and leash with winged infusion set designed to fit over the blood culture bottle (or syringe with appropriate blood transfer to vacutainer)

  5. Prep and position patient appropriately, apply tourniquet to palpate and identify appropriate vein. Hand hygiene (Moment 2),  put on sterile gloves, sterilise site (dry = 30s).

  7. Place 10mL blood per bottle (20mL/set, 40mL in total), keeping blood culture bottle upright and at/below the level of the venepuncture. Always collect/innoculate the blood culture bottles FIRST (innoculating the aerobic bottle first) then, if required, collect additional blood pathology tubes at this point
  8. Apply cotton ball and pressure to site (where possible obtain patient assistance to hold and apply pressure); repeat procedure for 2nd set of blood cultures at a different peripheral site, maintaining aseptic technique, invert bottles gently several times to prevent clotting

Do not cover any bar codes or the bottom of the bottle and place bottles into biohazard bag and arrange to send to the lab with request form, transport bottles at room temperature. Remove gloves and perform hand hygiene – (Moment 3, after the procedure). 1. Hand hygiene (moment 1), check patient ID, informed consent, ensure appropriate hx and tests on blood culture request form
  2. Collect equipment (including personal protection equipment) and place on a trolley cleaned with alcohol-based wipes. Sterile gloves, small dressing pack, cotton balls, tape, tourniquet(s). Two blood culture sets (4 bottles) comprising two aerobic and two anaerobic bottles. Check expiry date for each bottle and mark 10mL above the broth for fill level.
  3. Chlorhexidine gluconate (> 0.5%) with 70% alcohol solution, opened onto the sterile field. Vacutainer and leash with winged infusion set designed to fit over the blood culture bottle (or syringe with appropriate blood transfer to vacutainer) 
  4. Remove the cap of each blood culture bottle and using a non-touch technique scrub the vial stoppers well using a fresh chlorhexidine and 70% alcohol swab and allow to dry for 30 seconds
  5. Prep and position patient appropriately, apply tourniquet to palpate and identify appropriate vein. Hand hygiene (Moment 2),  put on sterile gloves, sterilise site (dry = 30s). 
  6. Perform venepuncture using vacutainer and leash with winged infusion set/luer adapter (release tourniquet during procedure where appropriate, this will contaminate the gloved hand and using a sterile towel or the non-dominant hand is advised)
  7. Place 10mL blood per bottle (20mL/set, 40mL in total), keeping blood culture bottle upright and at/below the level of the venepuncture. Always collect/innoculate the blood culture bottles FIRST (innoculating the aerobic bottle first) then, if required, collect additional blood pathology tubes at this point
  8. Apply cotton ball and pressure to site (where possible obtain patient assistance to hold and apply pressure); repeat procedure for 2nd set of blood cultures at a different peripheral site, maintaining aseptic technique, invert bottles gently several times to prevent clotting 
  9. Discard sharps, collect all rubbish/dirty items and dispose appropriately. Label each bottle with patient name, MRN, date/time for collection of blood and location of site used for each set. Do not cover any bar codes or the bottom of the bottle and place bottles into biohazard bag and arrange to send to the lab with request form, transport bottles at room temperature. Remove gloves and perform hand hygiene – (Moment 3, after the procedure). Inform px. Results not available for 48hrs
  10. {{c10::Document that (a) two sets of blood cultures have been taken, (b) from which sites, (c) include reason for site choice if this differs from a peripheral site. Do not delay administering antibiotics, do not wait for results}}

Why do we use 2 sets (4 bottles) when taking blood cultures?

• A single set (2 bottles) may miss up to 40% of bacteraemias/fungaemias 
  • if only one set is taken and found +ve it could be a contaminant (false positive result). 
  • Two sets showing growth makes it easier to eliminate the risk that a skin contaminant has been cultured. 
  • Taking blood from separate sites increases the assurance of a valid sample.
Do you have to wait between taking the first and second sets of blood cultures?
No, if 2 sets of blood cultures are taken from different peripheral sites and antibiotics have not been given, there is no reason to delay between taking the blood cultures.
What is inside an aerobe (liquid culture media) bottle for blood cultures?

Liquid culture media: transport medium that provides nourishment to microorganisms to encourage their growth
  • water, carbon + energy source, source of nitrogen, trace elements, maybe growth factors
What is inside an anaerobe blood culture bottle?

low oxygen content (boiled)
nutritional substitutes (vit K, haemin)
reducing agent (eg. 1% glucose - reduces oxidation potential)

How do you monitor patients on gentamicin?

Check plasma concentrations from 1st dose (so subsequent doses can be determined) and ensuring within maximum and minimum range

This ensures:
1. Adequacy of dosing while 
2. Reducing chance of Ototoxicity & nephrotoxicity
What are the main side effects of gentamicin?

• Nephrotoxicity
  • Ototoxicity
  • Vestibular toxicty
These S/E occur more frequently in patients with prolonged exposure to serum trough concentrations of greater than 2mcg/mL and renal insufficiency. 

Despite this, in renal failure from G-ve sepsis, gentamicin as a single dose is still indicated.

What is the anatomy of the lesser omentum?

2 fold peritoneal attachment between stomach and duodenum to the liver

Originate from lesser curvature of stomach and 1st part of duodenum

Attaches on groove of ligamentum teres and surrounding portal triad

Subsection of peritoneal canivty behind the stomach. 

Anterior wall = post. wall of the lesser omentum, post viscera of stomach and ant 2 layers of greater omentum

Posterior wall = posterior 2 layers of greater omentum, transverse mesocolon, pancreas, diaphragm

the communication between the lesser and greater sac

Bounded by
Front: free border of lesser omentum
Behind: periotneum covering IVC
Above (roof): peritoneum of caudate lobe of liver
Below (floor): periotneum covering commencement of duodenum and hepatic artery

1. Primary Investigations 
[[oc1::ECG (repeated) ]]
  • Possible findings on ECG: 
    • [[oc2::Peaked T waves, ]]
    • [[oc2::ST elevation ]]
    • [[oc2::T wave inversion (24h) ]]
    • [[oc2::q waves (3d), ]]
    • [[oc2::PE]]
Troponin T & I 
  • When is the peak elevation for Troponin, and how fast does it increase? 
    • [[oc3::Peaked 12-24hr (elevated for 1 wk). Increases in 2 hr, CK increases in 6hr ]]
  • What is Troponin 
    • [[oc4::Protein that regulated calcium mediated contraction of cardiac muscle ]]
  1. Secondary Investigations (Bloods) 
[[oc5::FBC – Exacerbating Anaemia or Infection (reduces O2 delivery) ]]
[[oc5::EUC – Potassium levels (risk of arrhythmia), Baseline (to detect progress towards shock) ]]
[[oc5::BGL – Diabetes if >11.1mmol/L (risk factor)]]
[[oc5::HbA1C – >7% (indicative of diabetes) ]]
[[oc5::Lipids – LDL ↑, HDL ↓, Total Chol ↑, TG↑ (risk factor → statin)]]

What is in the portal triad?

The term triad is a misnomer, coined before discovery of other components

Contains: 
  • proper hepatic artery
  • portal vein
  • common bile duct
  • lymphatics
  • branches of the vagus nerve

Consists of the [[oc1::Fundus]], [[oc2::Body]] and [[oc3::Neck]]

[[oc1::Fundus: which extends below the inferior margin of the liver, to contact the anterior abdominal wall behind the 9th R costal cartilages.]]
[[oc2::Body: continuing upwards from the fundus.]]
[[oc3::Neck: curves to become the cystic duct. The neck is attached to the liver by loose areolar tissue which contains the cystic A.]]

A 65 year old female who had a 10 year history of hypertension and a myocardial infarction three years previously, presented to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of weakness in  the left arm and leg.
 
On examination, her pulse was rapid and irregularly irregular. She had a left VII cranial nerve palsy of the upper motor neuron type and left spastic hemiparesis, with an ipsilateral upgoing plantar response

What is the lesion that caused this neurological deficit and what areas are likely to be affected?

1. R sided CVA caused by lenticulostriate artery occlusion or 
2. Haemorrhage (likely Charcot Bouchard aneurysm rupture) affecting internal capsule, basal ganglia and thalamus

A 65 year old female who had a 10 year history of hypertension and a myocardial infarction three years previously, presented to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of weakness in  the left arm and leg. 

On examination, her pulse was rapid and irregularly irregular. She had a left VII cranial nerve palsy of the upper motor neuron type and left spastic hemiparesis, with an ipsilateral upgoing plantar response

What are your differentials?

1. R sided MCA stroke (less likely in this case bc you would see contralateral sensory loss, cortical symptoms and a lower limb sparing)
  2. Brain tumour 
  3. Seizure with post-ictal deficit

How might this pathological process have occurred?

  1. Ischaemic stroke
    - [[oc1::cardiogenic]] embolus (Mural thrombus can be due to AF/MI)
    - [[oc2::carotid]] embolus (from atherosclerosis)

  2. Haemorrhagic stroke
    HTN --> accelerated atherosclerosis --> [[oc3::tunica media thinning]] --> [[oc4::aneurysm]] --> ruptures under HTN --> pressure oedema --> disrupts motor pathways

What is the anatomy and function of internal capsule?

The internal capsule is a [[oc1::white matter]] structure. White matter consists of myelinated and unmyelinated axons and glial cells such as [[oc2::astrocytes]], [[oc3::oligodendrocytes]], and [[oc4::microglial]] cells.

The internal capsule contains both ascending and descending axons --> carries info past the basal ganglia, separating the [[oc6::caudate nucleus]] and the [[oc7::thalamus]] from the [[oc8::putamen]] and the [[oc9::globus pallidus]]. 

The internal capsule is V-shaped when cut in a [[oc10::transverse]] plane and the bend called the genu  containing [[oc11::corticobulbar]] fibres, run between the [[oc12::cortex]] and the [[oc13::brainstem]].

  • The anterior limb is between the [[oc14::head of the caudate nucleus]] and the [[oc15::lenticular nucleus]]
  • The posterior limb is between the [[oc18::thalamus]] and [[oc19::lenticular nucleus]]
    - Contains [[oc20::corticospinal]] fibers, sensory fibers (including the [[oc21::medial lemniscus]] and the [[oc22::anterolateral system]]) from the body and a few [[oc23::corticobulbar]] fibers.

What is the anatomy and function of internal capsule?

The internal capsule is a {{c21::white matter}} structure. White matter consists of myelinated and unmyelinated axons and glial cells such as {{c21::astrocytes}}, {{c21::oligodendrocytes}}, and {{c21::microglial}} cells.

The internal capsule contains both ascending and descending axons --> carries info past the basal ganglia, separating the {{c21::caudate nucleus}} and the {{c21::thalamus}} from the {{c21::putamen}} and the {{c21::globus pallidus}}. 

The internal capsule is V-shaped when cut in a {{c21::transverse}} plane and the bend called the genu  containing {{c21::corticobulbar}} fibres, run between the {{c21::cortex}} and the {{c21::brainstem}}.

  • The anterior limb is between the {{c21::head of the caudate nucleus}} and the {{c21::lenticular nucleus}}
  • The posterior limb is between the {{c21::thalamus}} and {{c21::lenticular nucleus}}
    - Contains {{c21::corticospinal}} fibers, sensory fibers (including the {{c21::medial lemniscus}} and the {{c21::anterolateral system}}) from the body and a few {{c21::corticobulbar}} fibers.

What is the function of the head of caudate nucleus?

The caudate nucleus together with the [[oc1::putamen]] makes up the [[oc2::dorsal striatum]] part of the basal ganglia

  • Motor Functions
- [[oc3::Goal-directed movements]]: Translates idea to move into actual movement, contributes to body & limb posture and speed & accuracy of directed movements
- [[oc4::Spatial mnemonic processing]]: integrates spatial information with motor behaviour formulation
  • Cognitive Functions
    - [[oc5::Memory]], [[oc6::Learning]], [[oc7::Sleep]]

What functional areas does the MCA supply?

  • Superior division
1. [[oc1::Primary motor cortex]] (precentral gyrus): head shoulders, arms
2. [[oc2::Primary Somatosensory cortex]]  (postcentral gyrus): head, shoulders, arms
3. [[oc3::Association cortex]] (parietal lobe – abstract thinking/language/perception)
4. [[oc4::Broca’s area]] (inferior frontal gyrus of L  frontal lobe) 

  • Inferior division
1. [[oc5::Optic radiation ]]
2. [[oc6::Wernicke’s area]] (Sup. temporal gyrus L temp lobe) 
3. [[oc7::Putamen and GP via lenticulostriate aa]]

What does occlusion of MCA cause?

1. contralateral hemiplegia
  2. hemisensory loss of face & arm
  3. contralateral homonymouse hemianopia (disruption to optic radiation)
  4. dysphasia (dominant)
  5. visuospatial disturbance- cannot dress, gets lost (non dominant)
What types of deficits can unilateral cerebral strokes cause?

1. Motor control
  2. Somatic sensation
  3. Vision
  4. Not hearing, bc auditory information goes to both hemispheres
What effects do you see in occlusion of PCA?

• Supplies occipital lobe
  • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macula sparing. If bilateral --> cortical blindness
  • Possible visual agnosia (lack of recognition or understanding of visual objects or constructs)
  • Possible alexia  (disorders of reading)
What can lesions to lenticulostriate aa (of MCA) and Heubner aa (of ACA) cause?

• Pure motor loss: paralyis of face, arm & leg on one side OR
  • Pure sensory loss: mild hemi-numbness OR
  • Mixed sensori-motor
  • Ataxic hemiparesis

What is the blood supply to the visual system?

  1. [[oc1::Central retinal artery]]: retina
  2. [[oc2::Ophthalmic artery]]: optic nerve ([[oc3::prox. 2/3rd]]), muscles, lacrimal duct
  3. [[oc4::ACA]]: optic chiasm and intracranial optic nerve
  4. [[oc5::Anterior choroidal artery]] (branches off the internal carotid artery): Optic tract, lateral geniculate nucleus 
  5. [[oc6::Inferior branches of MCA]]: optic radiation
  6. [[oc7::Calcarine artery branch of PCA + MCA contributions]]: primary visual cortex (posterior pole of the occipital cortex)

Where is the primary visual cortex located?
On either side of the calcarine fissure of the occipital lobe, which is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery
What is the significacne of aneurysm of internal carotic to the visual system?
Internal carotid  is immediately lateral to the chiasm. Aneurysm can cause pressure on the chiasm and cause a partial, nasal hemianopia.

Describe the course and function of ophthalmic artery.

The ophthalmic artery is the first branch of the [[oc1::internal carotid artery]] and goes along the [[oc2::optic nerve]]. It gives off a branch, the [[oc3::central retinal artery]], that penetrates the optic nerve head to spread out over [[oc4::the inner surface of the retina]].

What are the most likely causes of death in the first two weeks following lesion to the internal capsule?

  1. [[oc1::Increased ICP]]
    - [[oc2::Vasogenic and cytotoxic oedema]] --> raised ICP --> tonsillar herniation --> [[oc3::cardiorespiratory failure]]
    - [[oc4::Superimposed haemorrhage]] --> raised ICP --> herniation --> cardiorespiratory failure
  2. Secondary stroke
    - [[oc5::Basilar artery]] --> [[oc6::cardiorespiratory centre hypoperfusion]] --> death
  3. [[oc7::Hospital related causes of death]]
    - PE from immobility and hypercoagulable state 
    - Aspiration pneumonia (impaired cough reflex, hypoventilation)
    - Hospital acquired infection --> Overwhelming sepsis 
          [[oc8::UTI]] (catheter) 
          [[oc9::Staph sepsis]] (cannula)
          [[oc10::Pressure sores]] (immobility)

Endocrine - homeostasis of blood glucose and stomach acid

What is the venous drainage of the region of the gallbladder?

1. into hepatic veins, to IVC (gallbladder)
2. into portal vein (bile duct)
What is the lymphatic drainage of the gallbladder?

hepatic nodes (in porta hepatis)
to pyloric nodes 
to coeliac nodes

Which parts of the duodenum are retroperitoneal?

2nd and 3rd

1st and 4th are intraperioneal, surrounded by peritoneum
Anatomical relations of the head of the pancreas

Anterior: tansverse colon, small intestines
Posterior: IVC, bile duct
Superior: 1st part of duodenum
Inferior: 3rd part of duodenum
Anatomical relations of the neck of the pancreas

Anterior: pylorus, lesser sac, gastroduodenal A, sup. pancreaticoduodenal A
Posterior: portal V, sup mesenteric V
Superior: splenic A
Anatomical relations of the body of the pancreas

Anterior: lesser sac, stomach, greater omentum, transv. mesocolon
Posterior: aorta, splenic V, sup. mesenteric A, L kidney, L suprarenal gland
Superior: splenic A, hepatic A, coeliac A
Anatomical relations of the tail of the pancreas

adjacent or embedded within spleen and splenic vessels
lies between the 2 layers of the ileorenal ligament
What is the arterial supply of the pancreas?

• Coeliac trunk → splenic A (neck, body tail) (arteria pancreatica magna) + superior pancreaticoduodenal A (head)
  • Superior mesenteric artery → inferior pancreaticoduodenal A (head)
What is the venous drainage of the pancreas?

Splenic vein → portal vein 
Sup pancreaticoduodenal vein → portal vein
Inferior pancreaticoduodenal vein → sup. mesenteric vein → portal vein
What is the nerve supply of the pancreas?

Parasympathetic: posterior vagal trunk and coeliac plexus (hormonal control more important than neural) 

Sympathetic: T6-10 via splanchnic nerves + coeliac plexus (postganglionic fibres run alongside blood vessels

Pain fibres: accompany sympathetic supply, T6-10 dermatome

28yo sexually active female presents with burning, frequency of urination and discharge

What is your provisional dx?

28yo sexually active female presents with burning, frequency of urination and discharge

What are your differentials?

  • Infection
- STI – [[oc1::urethritis]] or [[oc2::PID]] (chlamydia, gonorrhea)
- [[oc3::Vaginitis]] (vaginal discharge, itch, burning) 
  • Non-infectious
- [[oc4::Non-infectious urethritis]] (from mechanical irritation) 
- [[oc5::Over-active bladder]] (urgency, frequency, nil UTI) 
- [[oc6::Urothelial carcinoma]] 
- [[oc7::Urolithiasis]]

28yo sexually active female presents with burning, frequency of urination and discharge

What laboratory tests would you like to do?

  • [[oc1::MIDSTREAM Urine dipstick]]: nitrites ++, leukocytes ++  (will also tell you glucose, ketones, protein, etc.)
If +ve for nitrites and leukocytes then treat empirically. If –ve then consider these: 
  • URINE MCS 
- [[oc2::Microscopy and gram staining]] --> leukocytes and or bacteria (93% sensitive and 95% specific when positive)
- [[oc3::Culture & Sensitivity]]: diagnosed at [[oc4::> 10^8 CFU/L]] 
- EUC: check renal function 
- FBC, CRP, Blood cultures: if systemically unwell 
- [[oc5::Vaginal swab]] ?STI

What imaging would you like to do? (only in men, children, UTI, non-responsive, pyelonephritis/haematuria)

• Bladder Ultrasound: stone, tumour. 
  • Renal US & KUB X-ray

What contaminants could you find in an MSU?

• Normal skin or vaginal flora 
  • E. Coli
  • Squamous epithelial cells 
  • Staph saprophyticus

How would you do a MSU?

1. Wash hands & urethra + surrounding skin [[oc1::in normal SALINE]]
2. Begin urination (do not collect [[oc2::first urine passed 20-30mL]]) 
3. Collect urine midway through which is less likely to be contaminated 
4. Tightly cap container 
5. Wash hands 
6. Label container 
7. [[oc3::Take to lab as quickly as possible]] (reduce time allowed for further growth of organisms or alternatively, store at 4 degrees)

What can you find on a MSU dipstick?
protein, blood, albumin, glucose, ketones, leucocytes, nitrites, bilirubin, spec gravity, pH
What can you find on a MSU microscopy?
leucocytes, epithelial cells, red cells, bacteria, casts and crystals
What would you find on urinalysis if there is a UTI?
Which would you most likely see on urine microscopy if there is a UTI?
What organisms would you likely find on a gram stain if there is a UTI?

• gram –ve rods = e. coli, klebsiella, enterobacteria, pseudomonas
  • gram +ve cocci = staphylococcus saphrophyticus, enterococcus
What are the most common organisms for UTI?

1. E. Coli 70-95% (Gram -ve bacillus aerobic and facultative anaerobe)
2. Staph saprophytics 5-20% (gram +ve cocci facultative anaerobe)
3. Proteus mirabilis ~1% (gram -ve facultative anaerobe)
4. Other G-ve: klebsiella, pseudonomas aeruginosa, enterobacter
5. Other G+ve: eneterococcus, staph epidermidis

If you left the urine out for 4 hrs in room temperature, what would happen?
Organisms collected would grow by itself leading to falsely elevated bacterial counts
If you left the urine out for 4 hrs in room temp, what organisms can grow?

• Causative pathogen 
  • Commensals/natural flora (staph epidermidis, staph aureus, strep pyogenes)
If you left the urine out for 4 hrs in room temp, how would this affect the results?

• May give a false +ve if a large increase in a pathogenic organisms level was found 
  • May deem result useless as contaminated if commensals overgrow
If you left the urine out for 4 hrs in room temperature and the patient has been in hospital for 2 weeks catheterised, what organisms would grow?

How do we test for sensitivity of abx
  • CDS system = [[oc1::Calibration-Dichotomous-Susceptibility]] 
  • Organism is cultured on agar plates containing discs [[oc2::impregnated with different antibiotics]]. 
  • A [[oc3::zone of inhibition]] is seen around those antibiotics the micro-organism is sensitive to 
  • Zone of inhibition = area where no colonies are seen around the antibiotic impregnated disc. [[oc4::≥6mm annulus radius for most antibiotics, ≥2mm if vancomycin]] 
  • The disc itself is 6mm too, so basically a zone with an 18mm diameter must be found to say the micro-organism is susceptible.

Patient presents with a bee sting. Had been stung before but had only a mild response. 
Now presents with tachycardia, tachypnoea, pale, drowsy, angioedema and insp and exp stridor

What is your clinical dx?
Anaphylactic Shock (hypotensive, tachycardic, swollen tongue and urticaria) – a type of ‘distributive’ shock

Patient presents with a bee sting. Had been stung before but had only a mild response. 
Now presents with tachycardia, tachypnoea, pale, drowsy, angioedema and insp and exp stridor

What are your differentials?

Life Threatening
  • Status asthmaticus (atopic, stridor, tachypnoea) 
  • Other forms of shock (Cardiogenic, Obstructive, Hypovolaemic, Distributive) 
Non-life threatening (consider if patient not in shock): 
  • Urticaria/angio-oedema – medications 
  • Asthma 
  • Hyperventilation/panic attack

What would the emergency management for anaphylactic shock be?

Secure Airway: 
  1. Check for [[oc1::foreign body]]
  2. [[oc2::Intubate]] if necessary (airway oedema, trauma, altered respiration)
Check Breathing: 
  1. [[oc3::High flow O2 (>10L/min)]], elevate head of bed 
Provide Circulation support: 
  1. [[oc4::Raise legs above heart]]
  2. [[oc5::2 large bore cannula IV access]]
  3. [[oc6::Bolus]] 
  4. [[oc7::Give adrenaline IM 0.5mg]] (0.5mL of 1:1000) OR if no pulse [[oc8::IV 1mL of 1:10,000]]

What difference in function is there between giving adrenaline vs noradrenaline?

• Adrenaline (more affinity for β receptors --> bronchodilation) vs.
  • Noradrenaline (more affinity for α receptors --> vasoconstriction - use NorAd in septic shock)
How would you manage persistent hypotension in the context of anaphylactic shock?

1. Normal saline (max 50mL/kg)
  2. If cardiogenic cause- IV glucagon bolus 1-2mg
How would you manage upper airway obstruction in the context of anaphylactic shock?
How would you manage persistent wheeze in the context of anaphylactic shock?

1. Bronchodilators (salbutamol 8-12 puffs using spacer 100mcg, or 5mg salbutamol nebuliser)
  2. Oral prednisolone (1mg/kg, max 50mg)

What investigations would you do for anaphylactic shock?

  • Clinical dx
Bedside
  • [[oc1::ECG]] – must do before adrenaline, AMI 
  • [[oc2::Pulse oximetry]] 
Basics
  • [[oc3::ABG]] – mixed respiratory & metabolic acidosis 
  • [[oc4::FBC]] – eosinophilia 
  • [[oc5::EUC]] – renal impairment from shock & K levels in case of arrhythmia
Allergy-Specific
  • [[oc6::Serum tryptase (from mast cells)]] – elevated 1-3 hrs post anaphylaxis 
  • [[oc7::RAST – radioallergosorbent test]] (measures allergen specific IgE in serum): >0.35 IU/L to inciting antigens 
  • [[oc8::Skin test:]] >3mm diameter wheal (good to exclude food allergy) 
  • [[oc9::Challenge test]]
Imaging
  • CXR: exclude CHF, radio-opaque foreign body, pneumonia

PaO2 52 (lo)
PaCO2 (hi)
Bicarb 18 (lo)
Base excess -6 (lo)
O2 sat (lo)

  • Shows mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis (low pH) 
  • High PaCO2 = [[oc1::pharyngeal & laryngeal oedema]] --> airway obstruction --> [[oc2::inability to blow off CO2]]. This CO2 + H2O --> [[oc3::H2CO3]] --> acidosis. 
  • PaO2 and O2 Sat ↓= [[oc4::bronchiolar constriction]] impairs O2 exchange & low lung perfusion causes reduced gas exchange 
  • Low O2 = [[oc5::anaerobic metabolism]]--> [[oc6::lactic acidosis]] (anion gap should be [[oc7::↑]]) which uses up [[oc8::HCO3]] --> [[oc9::↓ HCO3 ]]

Provide pathophysiology behind clinical manifestations of anaphylactic shock
  • Inflammation
    - [[oc1::IgE-sensitized mast cells]] from prev. exposure causes degranulation and release of [[oc2::histamine]], [[oc3::tryptase]], [[oc4::PGD2]] and [[oc5::LTD4]] as well as chemotactic factors which all contribute to eventual [[oc6::leukocyte recruitment]] 
  • Bronchoconstriction
    - Tachypnoea and stridor – [[oc7::SMC contraction and laryngeal oedema]]
    - Wheeze and rhonchi – [[oc8::bronchospasm and mucous secretion]]
  • Urticaria and angioedema
    - [[oc9::Vasodilation and increased vascular permeability]]
  • Hypotension with associated poor end organ perfusion (pale, drowsy, incoherent + tachycardia)
    - [[oc10::Vasodilation and extravasation of fluid]]

Explain why patient has reacted with anaphylaxis only now and not previously

Allergic hypersensitivity (type 1) 
  • Mediated by [[oc1::IgE]] antibodies formed in response to a particular allergen/antigen. Bound to [[oc2::mast cells and basophils]]. In sensitised individuals, they respond by [[oc3::synthesising large amounts of IgE to an allergen]].
First exposure to allergen 
  • [[oc4::Dendritic cells]] take up allergen --> present to [[oc5::T cells]] --> differentiate into [[oc6::TH2 cells]] --> TH2 cells stimulate [[oc7::B cells into plasma cells]] --> [[oc8::making IgE]] --> IgE binds to [[oc9::FC component on mast cells]] (arming them) 
(only happens in susceptible people)

Later exposure to allergen (Anaphylaxis) 
  • Binds to IgE on mast cells --> [[oc10::crosslinks IgE]] --> mast cell degranulation 
  • 1° Mediator release (Initial – maximal at 15mins post exposure)
    - [[oc11::Histamine+ LTD4]]  --> [[oc12::↑ Vascular permeability, Vasodilation, Bronchoconstriction, Mucus]] 
    - Adenosine --> [[oc14::bronchoconstriction]] 
    - [[oc15::Tryptase]] --> [[oc16::inflammation and chemotactic factors]] for neutrophils & eosinophils

2° Mediator release (Late-phase – appears at 6hours persists for<72hrs) 
  • [[oc17::Phospholipase A2]] --> AA --> [[oc18::PG (bronchospasm)]] & [[oc19::LT (↑vascular permeability & bronchoconstriction)]] 
  • [[oc20::PAF]] --> platelet aggregation, histamine release & bronchospasm 
  • Mast-cell cytokines [[oc21::(TNF, IL-1, 4 ,5 ,6)]] --> recruit other inflammatory cells

Allergic hypersensitivity (type 1) 
  • Mediated by {{c21::IgE}} antibodies formed in response to a particular allergen/antigen. Bound to {{c21::mast cells and basophils}}. In sensitised individuals, they respond by {{c21::synthesising large amounts of IgE to an allergen}}.
First exposure to allergen 
  • {{c21::Dendritic cells}} take up allergen --> present to {{c21::T cells}} --> differentiate into {{c21::TH2 cells}} --> TH2 cells stimulate {{c21::B cells into plasma cells}} --> {{c21::making IgE}} --> IgE binds to {{c21::FC component on mast cells}} (arming them) 
(only happens in susceptible people)

Later exposure to allergen (Anaphylaxis) 
  • Binds to IgE on mast cells --> {{c21::crosslinks IgE}} --> mast cell degranulation 
  • 1° Mediator release (Initial – maximal at 15mins post exposure)
    - {{c21::Histamine+ LTD4}}  --> {{c21::↑ Vascular permeability, Vasodilation, Bronchoconstriction, Mucus}} 
    - Adenosine --> {{c21::bronchoconstriction}} 
    - {{c21::Tryptase}} --> {{c21::inflammation and chemotactic factors}} for neutrophils & eosinophils

2° Mediator release (Late-phase – appears at 6hours persists for<72hrs) 
  • {{c21::Phospholipase A2}} --> AA --> {{c21::PG (bronchospasm)}} & {{c21::LT (↑vascular permeability & bronchoconstriction)}} 
  • {{c21::PAF}} --> platelet aggregation, histamine release & bronchospasm 
  • Mast-cell cytokines {{c21::(TNF, IL-1, 4 ,5 ,6)}} --> recruit other inflammatory cells

Explain the mechanism of adrenaline
  1. Downregulates [[oc1::inflammatory mediator release]] from mast cells (i.e. histamine, tryptase) --> reduces [[oc2::urticaria, angioedema]] 
  2. α1/α2 agonist – [[oc3::vascular smooth m contraction]] --> [[oc4::↑peripheral vasoconstriction]] --> [[oc5::↑peripheral vascular resistance]] & [[oc6::↓oedema leakage]] --> [[oc7::↑BP]] + [[oc8::↓mucosal oedema]] 
  3. [[oc9::β2 agonist]] – bronchodilation 
  4. β1 agonist – [[oc10::+ve chronotropic (↑HR)]] and [[oc11::+ve inotropic (↑force of contraction)]] --> [[oc12::↑BP]]

46F presents for a routine Pap smear. She has been experiencing intermenstrual and post-coital bleeding. 
On speculum exam she has an ulcerated lesion on the cervix. Rest of the vaginal exam appears normal

What is your provisional dx?

46F presents for a routine Pap smear. She has been experiencing intermenstrual and post-coital bleeding. 
On speculum exam she has an ulcerated lesion on the cervix. Rest of the vaginal exam appears normal

What are your differential diagnoses?

Other neoplastic
  • Endometrial/vaginal ca
  • Cervical fibroids (leiomyoma)
  • Cervical endometrial polyp
Pre-malignant
  • CIN (cervical intra-epithelial neoplasia)
  • Cervical adenocarcinoma-in-situ
Infection
  • Cervicitis – infectious (HPV) 
  • PID (chlamydia – obligate intracellular, gonorrhoea – GN cocci)
Benign
  • Nabothian cyst – may be ruptured (cyst on cervix)
  • Endometriosis 
  • Cervical Ectropion – usually in pregnancy or younger women (endocervical protrusion)
What primary investigations would you do for cervical ca?

1. Speculum exam with Papanicolau test: cytobrush with endocervical and endometrial sampling  
  2. Colposcopy: for more definitive diagnosis  
    - Acetic acid staining of dyskaryotic cells --> Cone Biopsy
What laboratory investigations would you perform for cervical ca?

1. FBC: WCC (cervicitis), Hb low if excess bleeding from endometriosis 
  2. EUC & LFT: metastatic disease if suspicious of cervical cancer 
  3. Coagulation studies
  4. [HPV testing]
What imaging would you do for cervical ca?

• Transvaginal Ultrasound: allows good visualisation of cervix, uterus, ovaries and fallopian tubes to evaluate for tumours and cysts 
    - Pelvic U/S can be performed if TVUS did not visualise structures sufficiently 
  • CXR – screen for metastasis
  • Staging imaging – full body CT, PET, bone scan
What is the pathogenesis of cervical ca?

• HPV detected in 85-90% of precancerous lesions and invasive neoplasms
  • High-risk types = 16 [SCC] and 18 [adenoca]
  • Integrate DNA into genome of epithelial cells --> blocks TSGs P53 --> uncontrolled cellular proliferation
What types of pre-cancerous development can you get prior to cervical ca?

• CIN I, II and III (carcinoma in situ)
    - II and III = high grade requiring further colposcopy and diagnostic biospy
  • SIL (Squamous intra-epithelial lesion)

4 stages of HPV transmission?

  1. [[oc1::HPV transmission via microabrasions]]
  2. [[oc2::Acute HPV infection (anogenital warts?)]]
  3. [[oc3::Viral persistence + precancerous lesion]]
  4. [[oc4::Basement membrane invasion]]

4 stages of HPV transmission?

  1. {{c1::HPV transmission via microabrasions}}
  2. ...
  3. ...
  4. ...

  1. HPV transmission via microabrasions
  2. {{c2::Acute HPV infection (anogenital warts?)}}
  3. ...
  4. ...

  1. ...
  2. Acute HPV infection (anogenital warts?)

  4. ...

4 stages of HPV transmission?

  1. ...
  2. ...
  3. Viral persistence + precancerous lesion
  4. {{c4::Basement membrane invasion}}

4 stages of HPV transmission?

  1. {{c21::HPV transmission via microabrasions}}
  2. {{c21::Acute HPV infection (anogenital warts?)}}
  3. {{c21::Viral persistence + precancerous lesion}}
  4. {{c21::Basement membrane invasion}}
What prevention measure is there for cervical ca?

• HPV vaccine covering types 6,11,16 and 18
  • Given to women aged between 9-26 as a 3 part course
    - 0,2 and 6 months
What screening measures are in place for cervical ca and consider pros/cons?

• HPV screening for sexually active women 25-74YO every 5 years if low risk & first time 2 years after last normal pap 
Pros
  • Slow progression from CIN to invasive so therefore effective as a form of prevention (may even be 10-20 years)
  • Cervical cancer drop by 70-90% since intro
Cons
  • Cytology does not give clear structure of tissue

42 year old woman who discovered a hard non-tender breast lump 15mm in diameter, cousin had breast cancer

What is your provisional dx?

42 year old woman who discovered a hard non-tender breast lump 15mm in diameter, cousin had breast cancer

What are your differential diagnoses?

Non-malignant
  1. Cystic/fibrocystic change (pain during luteal phase)
  2. Fat necrosis (hx of trauma)
  3. Breast Abscess or mastitis
  4. Lipoma
Malignant – non-invasive
  1. DCIS
  2. Paget’s disease (extension of DCIS into lactiferous ducts and areola)
  3. LCIS
Malignant  - Invasive
  1. Invasive ductal cell carcinoma
  2. Invasive lobular cell carcinoma
  3. Medullary carcinoma
  4. Colloid/mucoid carcinoma
What further hx would arouse suspicion of breast ca?

1. Size change: gradual increase = cancer, fluctuating = fibrocystic change 
  2. Axillary Lymphadenopathy 
  3. Systemic features (weight loss, night sweats, setc.) and signs of metastases (lung, bone, liver)
  4. Prev hx 
  5. Family hx – 1°, genetic (BRCA ½)
What exam findings would arouse further suspicion of breast ca?

• Systemic signs --> cachexia
  • Mets screen- peripheries (lymphadenopathy), bony tenderness, hepatomegaly, resp (cough/pneumonia)
Breast 
  1. Overlying skin changes (erythema, peau d’orange – skin dimpling)
  2. Nipple inversion, discharge and signs of pargets
  3. Palpation (fixed/mobile, hardness, tenderness, irregularity)
  4. Hard, irregular, non-tender = malignant
  5. Well-circumscribed, mobile, rubbery = fibroadenoma
Significance of family hx and breast ca?

1. A 1o Relative with unilateral Breast Ca = 2.0x RR increase 
  2. A 1o Relative with bilateral Breast Ca = 5.0x RR increase 
  3. Family hx of ovarian ca = 5.0x RR increase

List other risk factors for breast ca
  • Related pathology
    - [[oc1::LCIS or DCIS]] = 7-12x RR 
    Past history = 5.0x RR 
  • Family hx of [[oc2::ovarian cancer]] = 5.0x RR 
  • Age [[oc3::>50]] = 4.0x RR 
  • [[oc4::BRCA1/2 (AD - tumour suppressor genes) +ve]] = 4.0x RR 
  • [[oc5::High oestrogen exposure]] 
  • [[oc6::Smoking]] = 1.5x RR

What are some causes of increased estrogen exposure?

• Nulliparous = 3.0x RR 
  • First live birth >35 = 1.9x RR 
  • Overweight/obese = 1.5x RR 
  • Late menopause = 1.5x RR 
  • OCP = 1.2x RR increase

Dx for breast ca requires Triple Assessment
  1. Clinical examination – Lump and nodes 
  2. Imaging (U/S <35, mammography+ US >35) 
  3. Biopsy for Cytology/histology
When do you use U/S vs mammogram?

• <35y = US only, mammogram useless as breast tissue too dense 
  • >50y = mammogram +/- US as breast is less dense (more adipose, less ligaments & ducts by %)

Does fibrocystic change predispose to carcinoma?

Benign breast lesions can be classified histologically into three categories: 
  1. Non-proliferative e.g. [[oc1::breast micro/macro cyst]], [[oc2::stromal fibrosis]]
    - Exaggerated response of normal breast changes that occurs in menstrual  cycle
    - [[oc3::Confers negligible increased risk]] of carcinoma 
  2. Proliferative e.g. [[oc4::Epithelial hyperplasia]], [[oc5::sclerosing adenosis]] (glandular aggregation and fibrous overgrowth)
    - Small increased risk of developing breast cancer = [[oc6::1.5-2.5x]]
  3. Atypical lobular hyperplasia = x5 risk

Does fibrocystic change predispose to carcinoma?

  1. Non-proliferative e.g. {{c1::breast micro/macro cyst}}, ...
    - Exaggerated response of normal breast changes that occurs in menstrual  cycle

  2. Proliferative e.g. ..., ... (glandular aggregation and fibrous overgrowth)
    - Small increased risk of developing breast cancer = ...
  3. Atypical lobular hyperplasia = x5 risk

  3. Atypical lobular hyperplasia = x5 risk

Does fibrocystic change predispose to carcinoma?

Benign breast lesions can be classified histologically into three categories: 
  1. Non-proliferative e.g. ..., ...
    - Exaggerated response of normal breast changes that occurs in menstrual  cycle
    - Confers negligible increased risk of carcinoma 
  2. Proliferative e.g. {{c4::Epithelial hyperplasia}}, ... (glandular aggregation and fibrous overgrowth)
    - Small increased risk of developing breast cancer = ...
  3. Atypical lobular hyperplasia = x5 risk

Grade

Stage

Discuss features of breast cancer pot

Macroscopic

Microscopic
  • Heterogenous tubule formation 
  • Invasion into adipose tissue

1. [[oc1::airway obstruction. Intubate if impending respiratory distress. Surgical airway if laryngeal injury]]
  2. [[oc2::Consider haemothorax or pneumothorax.
    • Low cervical injury = paradoxical breathing (inward movement of abdo as chest expands due to loss of phrenic nerve)]]
  3. [[oc3::Control bleeding. Fluid resus w/ IV access
    • neurogenic shock vs hypovolaemic shock = loss of sympathetic tone throughout body - mass vasodilation]]
  4. [[oc4::Neurological deficits - weakness, numbness. Complete vs incomplete SCI - based on presence of anal tone]]
  5. [[oc5::Check neck is concealed by cervical collar. Once stable, evaluate if surgical referral is required]]

C1: [[oc1::Hard palate + anterior arch of atlas]]
C2-3: [[oc2::lower borders of mandible]]
C3: [[oc3::Hyoid bone]]
C4-6: [[oc4::Thyroid cartillage ]]
C6: [[oc5::Cricoid cartillage]]
C6-T5: [[oc6::Trachea]]
What landmarks can you identify on imaging at each level of the Cervical spine?

C1: {{c21::Hard palate + anterior arch of atlas}}
C2-3: {{c21::lower borders of mandible}}
C3: {{c21::Hyoid bone}}
C4-6: {{c21::Thyroid cartillage }}
C6: {{c21::Cricoid cartillage}}
C6-T5: {{c21::Trachea}}
What lesion do you see?
C6/7 dislocation w/ associated fracture and bilateral dislocated facets.
What provides stability to the cervical spine?
2 vertical columns: anterior and posterior columns
What are the components of the anterior column of the cervical spine?

• Vertebral bodies
  • disc spaces
  • Ant + Pos longitudinal ligaments
  • intervertebral discs (annulus fibrosus)
What are the components of the posterior column of the cervical spine?

• pedicles
  • facets
  • apophyseal joints
  • lamina
  • spinous process
  • posterior ligament complex
What differentiates a stable and unstable Cervical Spine Injury?

If one column is intact, the injury is stable
If both columns are disrupted, the injury is unstable

 Stable

    The structural stability of the spine remains intact.
    No neurologic deficits

Unstable

    The structural stability of the spine is compromised.
    The spine can move as two or more independent units, which may cause spinal cord injury.
What are radiographic features of unstable subluxtion injury of the cervical spine?

1. anterior subluxation >4mm
  2. Associated compression fracture of >25% of vertebral body
  3. Increase/Decrease of disc space
  4. Fanning of the interspinous distance
Do spinal nerves emerge above or below the level of the vertebrae?

From C1 to C7: above the associated vertebrae
C8: below C7
T1 onwards: below the associated vertebrae

Flexion Teardrop Fracture

from hyperflexion. Can cause ant. cervical cord syndrome due to displacement of post. vertebral body onto spinal cord

C2,3,4: [[oc1::
  • Death - respiratory failure
  • C4 - loss of all upper limb function except scapula elevation (trapezius via CN XI)]]
C5: [[oc2::
  • Some respiratory impairment (weakness of diaphragm)
  • Biceps + Brachioradialis reflex lost (C5/6) 
  • Loss of upper limb function]]
C6: [[oc3::
  • LMN weakness of shoulder abduction, adduction, elbow flexion, wrist extension (C5/6) and UMN weakness for all muscles supplied below C6
  • bowel + bladder incontinence
  • parasthesiae in C6 dermatomes and below]]
C7+T1: [[oc4::
  • Gross arm+forearm function retained
  • Impaired hand function - small muscles of hand (C7, C8, T1)
  • Loss of triceps reflex (C7/8)
  • UMN hyper-reflexia below this level
  • Loss of sensation from little finger to medial arm + forearm to axilla (C7-T1 dermatome)]]
L1/L2:  [[oc5::
  • LMN weakness below this level (formation of cauda equina @ this level) (motor neurons for spinal levels below L1/2 synapse at L1/2)]]

5 year mortality for quadraplegia [[oc1::~ 10%]]

Lungs/Diaphragm: [[oc2::Respiratory failure, pneumonia, atelectasis]]
Vascular: [[oc3::DVT and PE]]
Bladder: [[oc4::
  • Urinary retention (bladder flaccidity from LMN – cauda equina OR spinal shock – acute UMN injury lasting up to 2-3 mths) 
  • Requires catheterisation for overflow incontinence
  • At risk of UTI +/- vesicoureteric reflux]]
Bowel: [[oc5::Paralytic Ileus]]
Skin: [[oc6::Pressure sores]]
ANS:[[oc7::
  • Neurogenic shock – interruption of autonomic pathway leading to decr. Vascular resistance and bradycardia → decr. BP
  • Autonomic dysreflexia from injury @ or above C6 (sensory - usually noxious - stimuli from below lesion causes reflex sympathetic activatoin. SNS overactivity below lesion uncontrolled due to isolation from vasomotor centres of brain. Widespread vasoconstriction → malignant hypertension. Brain detects rise in BP from baroreceptors, inbihitory signals cannot pass through SC, PNS reaction above level of lesion. Impulses travelling via vagus nerve cause Secondary bradycardia.
Musculoskeletal: [[oc8::Spasticity (increased reflexes and stiffness in limbs below lesion)]]

What are the clinical features of Central Cord Syndrome?

Bilateral limb weakness + loss of pain and temperature
upper usually more affected than lower extremities
What are the clinical complications of Anterior Cord Syndrome?

• Loss of temp and pain at + below lesion
  • Flaccid paraparesis at segment level (dmg to both anterior horns)
  • Bilateral Spastic paraparesis below segment (bilateral dmg to pyramidal tract)
  • bladder and rectum dysfunction (dmg to lateral horns)
What are the clinical features of Posterior Cord Syndrome?
Ipsilateral loss of proprioception, vibration, and touch below level of lesion
What are the clinical features of Brown-Séquard syndrome?

Ipsilateral:
  • Loss of proprioception, vibration, and tactile discrimination below the level of the lesion
  • Segmental flaccid paresis at the level of the lesion, spastic paralysis below the level of the lesion, and ipsilateral Babinski sign
Contralateral: loss of pain and temperature sensation one or two levels below lesion
What are the 2 types of Spinal Cord Injury?

34 y.o. woman presents with new rash on face, lethargy, malaise and arthralgia. Had multiple previous miscarriages.
What are your differentials?

Connective Tissue Disorders

  • SLE (malar rash, arthralgia, miscarriages) +/- antiphospholipid syndrome
  • RA (symmetrical small join bilateral polyarthropathy, DIP sparing
  • Seronegative arthritis
    • Psoriatic arthritis (w/ characteristic rash)
    • Reactive arthritis (assoc. w/ infection - chlamydia, shigella, salmonella) (Reiter's syndrome - triad: urethritis, conjunctivitis/uveitis, arthritis)
    • sacroiliac athropathy
  • Mixed CT disease: dermatomyositis, polymyositis
  • Scleroderma: (CREST syndrome - calcinosis, Raynaud's phenom, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, telangiectasia)
    • no rash
  • Acne rosacea
What are some connective tissue disorders that you know of?

Autoimmune disorders that are classified under systemic rheumatic disease
  • RA
  • SLE
  • Primary Sjögren syndrome
  • dermatomyositis
  • polymyositis
  • sclerosis (diffuse/limited)
  • mixed CTD (combination of SLE, polymyositis, systemic sclerosis)
  • Ehlers Danlos Syndrome

34 y.o. woman presents with new rash on face, lethargy, malaise and arthralgia. Had multiple previous miscarriages.
What investigations would you perform?

Bedside
  • Urinalysis (SLE glomerulonephritis)
Bloods
  • FBC (thrombocytopenia, pancytopenia)
  • ESR, CRP (may indicate severity of disease)
  • EUC, LFTs
  • Autoimmune screen
    • ANA (Antinuclear antibodies) + immunoflourescence (SLE ~95% sensitivity, low spec)
    • Anti dsDNA  (SLE low sensitivity, high spec)
    • ENA (Extractable nuclear antibodies)
    • ANCA (Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies)
    • C3, C4 protein
    • RF (rheumatic factor) (70%RA, <40% SLE)
    • Anti-CCP (96% spec. RA)
  • Blood cultures (if signs of infection)
  • TSH, Fe studies
Imaging
  • X-ray (chest (infection), hands, feet (arthritis))

antibodies directed against nuclear components of cells 

Sensitivity: 95% SLE, ~90%MCT, 70-90% scleroderma, 80% CREST, 30% RA, 70% autoimmune hepatitis

• HEp-2 cells are a cell line mimicking human cells with permeable membranes
  • serum taken from pt, diluted to 1/80, 1/160, 1/320, 1/640, 1/1280, 1/3000
  • diluted serum added to slides with cells, Abs bind to intracellular components
  • Ab added for the specific Ab, contains flourescent labelling
  • Cells placed under microscope, light shone, if it lights up - +ve titre
  • if 1/320 and more dilute lights up, is considered +ve
What are some immunoflourescence patterns for ANA tests?
What are examples of Extractable nuclear antigens (ENAs)?

• Ro (SLE 40%. common in Sjögren's syndrome)
  • La (SLE 15%. common in Sjögren's syndrome)
  • Smith (Sm) (SLE 10-50%)

Even more rare for SLE:
  • U1RNP (common in mixed connective tissue disease + overlap syndromes)
  • Scl-70 (topoisomerase) (common in diffuse systemic sclerosis)
  • RNA polymerase III (25% in diffuse systemic sclerosis)
  • Jo1
What are some ANA staining patterns?

• Nucleolar - common in SLE and other CTD
  • Centromere - rare in SLE, common in limited systemic sclerosis
  • Speckled - common in SLE and other CTD
  • Homogenous - uncommon in SLE, rare in CTD
What is the sensitivity of Anti dsDNA for SLE?
What are examples of antiphospholipid antibodies?

• Lupus anticoagulant
  • Anticardiolipin
  • IgM APL
  • IgG APL
  • beta-2-glycoprotein 1
5-10% frequency in SLE

Diagnostic of antiphospholipid syndrome

4/11 of the criteria
MD SOAP BRAIN
  • Malar rash
  • Discoid Rash

  • Serocitis
  • Oral ulcers
  • Arthritis
  • Photosensitivity

  • Blood (pancytopenia - anaemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia)
  • Renal (protein, glomerulonephritis)
  • ANA
  • Immunologic (dsDNA, ENA, etc)
  • Neurologic (psych disturbance, seizures)
OR
ORDER HIS ANA

  • O – Oral ulcer
  • R – Rash (Malar)
  • D – Discoid rash
  • E – Exaggerated Photosensivity
  • R – Renal Disorders (proteinuria, cellular casts)

  • H – Hematological Disorder (hemolysis, Thrombocytopenia)
  • I – Immunological disrder (anti-dsDNA, LE cell)
  • S – Serositis (pleuritis, pericarditis)

  • A – Arthritis
  • N – Neurological disorders (Szr, psychosis)
  • A – Antinuclear Antibody
What are some complications of antiphospholipid syndrome?

CLOT
  • coagulopathy (DVT, PE, venous ulcer, splinter haemorrhages, stroke, MI, ischaemia)
  • Livedo reticularis (swelling veins - swottling purple rash)
  • Obstetric complications (miscarriage/premature birth) (thrombosis of placental vessels - ischaemia)
  • Thrombocytopenia (consumptive)
autoimmune disease that increases the risk of thrombosis as a result of procoagulatory antibodies.
What is the etiology of antiphospholipid syndrome?

Primary.
Secondary
  • SLE
  • RA
  • neoplasm
  • HIV, Hepatitis A/B/C
  • Bacterial infections (eg. syphilis, Lyme disease, TB)
What is the pathophysiology of antiphospholipid syndrome?

Formation of procoagulatory antiphospholipid antibodies
  • Ab form complexes with anticoagulant proteins (eg. protein C/S, antithrombin III), inactivating them
  • Ab can activate platelets and vascular endothelium - inc. binding of platelets
Leads to a hypercoagulable state → ↑ risk of thrombosis and embolism
Haematology Lab Visit: What is a mixing study?

for coagulation

The patient's plasma is mixed with normal plasma. If the prolonged aPTT is caused by a lack of clotting factors, the factors contained in the normal plasma will normalize the aPTT. 

In the presence of lupus anticoagulant, the aPTT will remain unchanged.
What is the Russell viper venom test for Lupus Anticoagulant?
Lupus anticoagulant interacts with Russell viper venom, which usually induces the formation of blood clots. As LA binds the venom, this effect is suppressed, resulting in a prolonged aPTT.
What serology can be conducted for antiphospholipid antibodies?

Lupus anticoagulant (leads to prolonged aPTT)
  • mixing study
  • Russell viper venom test
Anticardiolipin antibodies (aCL)
  • patients with APS often test false +ve for syphilis (VRDL, RPR) as the antigen used in syphilis tests is cardiolipin
Anti-beta 2- glycoprotein antibodies

34 y.o. woman presents with new rash on face, lethargy, malaise and arthralgia. Had multiple previous miscarriages.
How would you manage this patient?

• Education, support, reassurance
  • use broad spectrum SPF 50+ sunscreen
  • Refer to rheumatologist for shared care
  • Acute management
    • SC LMWH or IV unfractionated heparin
    • NSAIDs, steroid cream (hyrocortisone)
    • hydroxychloroquine (anti-malarials???MOA???)
    • In severe cases: high-dose glucocorticoids (pred), immunosuppressants (azathioprine, methotrexate), plasmapheresis, and/or immunoglobulins
  • Secondary prophylaxis
    • Low risk: low-dose aspirin
    • High risk, no desire to become pregnant: long-term treatment with oral warfarin
    • If wishes to have children, prevention of miscarriage: LMWH + aspirin
    • NSAIDs, hydroxychloroquine
What is the pathophysiology of photosensitiviy in SLE?
formation of antigen-antibody complexes that are deposited in the skin. Prone to reaction to UV light
What is the pathophysiology of Lupus nephritis/
formation of antibody-antigen complexes, deposition in the kidneys leading to glomerulonephritis

What are some outcomes of a hepatitis infection?

4 Cs
  • Carrier: Individuals who carry the virus but who do not suffer recurrent bouts of replication with inflammation 
  • Chronic infection (HCV but some HBV): 
    • People who carry the virus (circulating RNA/DNA persists) and who suffer recurrent bouts of viral replication and inflammation. 
  • Cirrhosis:  chronic infection and inflammation results in progressive fibrosis and parenchymal destruction with micro & macronodules 
  • HCC: rare event overall but may occur in up to 5% of those with HCV. 
    • Likely due to persistent inflammation +/- incorporation of HBV X gene which wildly activates genes.

35yo homosexual male with a 2 week history of nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea. Fever 38.6, hepatosplenomegaly and jaundice. He is a chef and previous IVDU
Interpret his results:

• AST & ALT ↑ >10x normal = hepatic injury
    • AST:ALT ratio: <1 = viral 
  • Bilirubin ↑: 
    • breakdown product of porphyrin part of haem, ↑ levels indicate it is not being excreted in bile but accumulating in blood = obstructive jaundice 
  • Alk Phosphatase ↑: 
    • enzyme found in liver & bone. 
    • ↑ suggests cholestasis where obstruction → increased synthesis and secretion. 
  • Gamma Glutamyltransferase ↑: 
    • enzyme of hepatocytes and bile duct epithelium and is a non-specific marker of early liver disease.

35yo homosexual male with a 2 week history of nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea. Fever 38.6, hepatosplenomegaly and jaundice. He is a chef and previous IVDU
What results would confirm a diagnosis of Hepatitis A?

• Anti-hepatitis A virus immunoglobulin M
    • Diagnosis = immunoglobulin M (IgM) antibody to HAV. 
      • Positive IgM at symptom onset and rise in ALT/AST
    • Good sensitivity, specificity → FPs are uncommon
    • Remain positive for usually 3-6mths (unless relapsing)
  • Anti-hepatitis A virus immunoglobulin G
    • Anti-HAV IgG appears after IgM + persists for many years. 
    • Anti-HAV IgG in the absence of IgM = past infection or vaccination rather than acute infection. 
    • IgG provides protective immunity.
Discuss the complications of the hepatitis viruses

• Fulminant hepatic failure (hep. B, hep. A)
    • Toxic: 
      • Nitrogenous/ammonia waste build up → cerebral oedema → encephalopathy 
      • Decreased drug metabolism
    • Endocrine:
      • Glucose storage dysfunction
      • Hyperoestrogenism
    • Hypoalbuminaemia: Oedema and ascites
    • Coagulopathy: decr. production of coag. fx
  • CLD and Cirrhosis (Hep. C, hep. B)
  • HCC (Hep. B, Hep. C)

Hepatitis A infection.
After managing the disease in the individual, what will you do?

• Notify local Public Health Unit 
    • Childcare and food services are the most important for Hep A contact tracing
    • Chef must be off work for at least 6 weeks to clear virus.
  • Then follow guidelines for managing people at child care, health care or restaurants/food industry. 
  • Normal immunoglobulin of 0.02ml/kg IM is given to 
    • Household and sexual contacts of case 
    • Staff and children in close contact with a case in a childcare centre
Patient recently had abdominal surgery. What's wrong with his medications?

• Full name required
  • Paracetamol should be written as dose, not tablets
    • can be given as 1g PO QID, not PRN, may also reduce opioid requirements
  • PRN morphine generally not appropriate on the wards
    • IM not as useful as IV (slow titration, repeated injections)
    • Should be IV PCA - 0.02mg/kg with a 10min lockout (0.1mg/kg loading dose)
    • dosing interval should be shorter to reduce troughs
  • Other: ondansetron is useful, but metoclopramide is cheaper
Why is it appropriate to treat post-operative pain?

• Patient satisfaction and QoL
  • Early mobilisation
  • Reduced hospital stay and costs
What Pre-operative factors may increase post-op pain?

• psychological vulnerability, anxiety and fear
  • younger aged adults
  • female
  • obesity
  • pre-existing pain
What intra-operative factors may increase post-op pain?

• extent of tissue damage
  • site/location of surgery
What post-operative factors may increase post-op pain?
How would you monitor someone for post-op pain?

• pain
    • just asking if analgesia is appropriate
    • visual analogue scale
    • numerical rating scale
  • Infection
    • surgical site
    • vital signs
  • opioid use (PCA)
    • check for level of sedation in case of resp. depression
  • monitor fluid and electrolyte status in patient who is vomiting

Patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) = pain relief that allows a patient to self-administer small doses of an analgesic as required. 
  • The PCA pump allows patients to self-administer fixed bolus doses of opioid in response to pain. 
  • Can be used with the subcutaneous or epidural route.
  • PCA is a maintenance therapy, the patient’s pain should be controlled with individually titrated doses before starting PCA, however loading dose can be programmed
  • The most common form involves the use of a programmable intravenous pump.
    • IV allows rapid titration by the patient + shorter lockout interval (usually 5 minutes).
What are some benefits of patient controlled analgesia?

Benefits
  • Patients can administer opioids as often as required, within the limits preset by the prescriber. 
  • Improved comfort, by avoiding the peaks and troughs of analgesia associated with other methods of parenteral administration. 
  • + patients can anticipate and treat incident pain (eg pain associated with mobilisation or physiotherapy). 
  • Lower incidence of hypoxaemia in patients receiving PCA opioids than in those receiving intramuscular opioids.

How would you dose PCA morphine?

Less than 50kg: 0.5 mg/kg diluted to a total volume of 50 mL with normal saline
Bolus dose:  2 mL = 20 microgram/kg 
*Background: 0.5 mL/hr = 5 microgram/kg/hr

More than 50kg: 50 mg diluted to a total volume of 50 mL with normal saline
Bolus dose: 1 mL = 1 mg
*Background: 0.5 mL/hr = 0.5 mg/hr
What do you have to consider before you prescribe PCA morphine?

• Patient age, disease, weight and opioid naivety
    • Liver disease (1st pass metabolism), 
    • Renal disease (excretion), 
    • respiratory illness (depression, CLD causing HF, upper airway obstruction)

What is the MOA of paracetamol?

• Analgesia: ↓ central PG synthesis (? COX-3 inhibition) AND Modulates descending inhibitory serotinergic (5HT) pain pathways. 
  • Anti-pyretic: ↓ PG synthesis in hypothalamus
What are some side effects of paracetamol?

• 0.5-1g 4-6hrly PO (max 4g total a day)
  • 15mg/kg for children
If the patient was an IVDU, how would you alter his opioid pain management?

In opioid-tolerant patients, treatment should aim to provide effective analgesia while minimising tolerance and preventing withdrawal
  • Increase dose with appropriate monitoring for resp. depression
  • Oxycodone (x3 potency of morphine), fentanyl (rapid acting and potent), hydromorphine
  • Background infusion to establish ‘baseline’ opioid requirement
  • Multimodal pain relief
  • Tramadol (for neuropathic pain)
What are some features of opioid withdrawal?

Withdrawal – associated with dependence
  • Starts after a few hours and can last several days. 
  • Not life threatening 
  • Causes tremor, vomiting, sweating, diarrhoea, anxiousness, aggression 
  • Consider methadone where analgesia is also needed

What is the physiology of nausea and vomiting?
  • The central neural regulation of vomiting is vested in two separate units in the medulla:
    • [[oc1::The vomiting centre and the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ)
    • The CTZ is sensitive to chemical stimuli and is the main site of action of many emetic and anti-emetic drugs
    • It is also believed δ  & μ receptors play a role which would explain how opiates so regularly cause nausea and vomiting]]
  • Pathophys: [[oc2::The BBB is relatively permeable near the CTZ → activation by circulating emetic toxins → impulses pass through vomiting centre → visceral and somatic functions involved in vomiting]]
  • The main neurotransmitters in the control of vomiting are [[oc3::ACh, histamine, 5-HT and dopamine]]
  • These are relevant areas for anti-emetic drugs to work:
    • [[oc4::Odansetron – 5-HT3 antagonist
    • Metoclopramide – D2 antagonits]]

What is the MOA of ondansetron?
Blocks 5HT3 (serotonin) receptors at the CTZ centrally + at visceral autonomic afferent neurons in foregut → ↓ signalling to vomiting centre
What are some side effects of ondansetron?

• Headaches
  • constipation
  • flushing + vision changes w/ large IV bolus
  • 0.1% risk of seizure
What are some indications for ondansetron?

• prevention of post-op nausea and vomiting
  • preventing N+V as a side effect of morphine
  • prevent abdominal straining due to pain (protect surgical site)
what is the MOA of metclopramide?

• Acts on chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) centrally. Antiemetic action through antagonism of dopamine receptors (D2)
  • It also stimulates motility of the upper gastrointestinal tract, increasing the gastric emptying rate and reducing small intestinal transit time. 
    • thought to be mediated by release of ACh in the myenteric plexus.
What are some side effects of metoclopramide?

• Restlessness, drowsiness, dizziness and headache. 
  • Anxiety and agitation can occur, particularly following intravenous administration.
  • Extrapyramidal adverse effects
  • Long-term = tardive dyskinesia, particularly in elderly people.

What is a common antibiotic prophylaxis for abdominal surgery?

• The most common contaminating organisms are 
    • Aerobic Gram-negative bacilli (eg Escherichia coli, Klebsiella species) 
    • Anaerobic Gram-negative organisms (eg Bacteroides species) depending on site and rx fx
  • For prophylaxis, use:
    • metronidazole 500 mg (child: 12.5 mg/kg up to 500 mg) IV, ending the infusion at the time of induction
      • PLUS EITHER
    • cephazolin 1 g (adult 80 kg or more: 2 g) (child: 25 mg/kg up to 1 g) IV, at the time of induction
      • OR
    • gentamicin (adult and child) 2 mg/kg IV, at the time of induction.

  • If there is evidence of peritonitis due to perforated viscus
    • amoxy/ampicillin 1 g (child: 25 mg/kg up to 1 g) IV, 6-hourly
      • PLUS
    • gentamicin 4 to 6 mg/kg (severe sepsis: 7 mg/kg) (child less than 10 years: 7.5 mg/kg; 10 years or more: 6 mg/kg [severe sepsis: 7 mg/kg]) IV, for 1 dose to monitor
    • metronidazole 500 mg (child: 12.5 mg/kg up to 500 mg) IV, 12-hourly.
If IV therapy is required beyond 72 hours, cease the gentamicin-containing regimen and use piperacillin+tazobactam or ticarcillin+clavulanate.
What are some complications of surgical anaesthesia?

• Anaphylaxis (0.2%)
  • Respiratory depression
  • Cardiovascular collapse – decompensation by hypovolemia and hypotension 
  • Idiosyncratic reactions related to specific agents - eg, malignant hyperpyrexia with suxamethonium, succinylcholine-related apnoea
  • Damage to teeth
  • Sore throat, laryngeal damage
  • Nerve injury - 0.4% in general anaesthesia and 0.1% in regional anaesthesia
  • Awareness during anaesthesia
  • Haemorrhage
  • Hypothermia
  • Hypoxic brain damage 
  • Death

What is the likely cause of her anaemia?
Iron deficiency Anaemia (chronic blood loss – GIT, menstrual)

18 y.o. woman brought in by ambulance to ED w/ uncontrolled haemorrhage after wisdom tooth extraction. She had always "bruised easily" and often experienced "heavy periods". No previous operations

What other tests would you order?

Bedside: FOBT
Bloods: 
  • FBC
  • Coagulation studies + mixing studies (exclude Haem A)
  • LFTs (hepatic dysfunction)
  • EUCs (uraemia)
  • Iron studies (decreased serum iron, ferritin, increased total iron binding capacity, transferrin )
How would you treat Von Wilebrand's disease?

Desmopressin (DDVAP)
  • ADH analogue which = release of vWF and factor VIII from endothelial stores
  • For those with minor bleeds 
Cryoprecipitate w/ Factor VIII + fibrinogen + vWF
  • vWF is important as a carrier protein for factor VIII (required as a co-enzyme for factor X conversion in intrinsic pathway)
  • vWF also enables binding to GpIb receptors on platelet membranes activating adherence and aggregation properties (GPIIb/IIIa) – aka platelet activation and adhesion
Is a patient with Von Wilebrand's disease at risk of spontaneous bleeding into joints (haemarthrosis)?

No, haemarthrosis is rare and usually occurs in the presence of significant factor deficiencies (coagulopathies)

vWF disease affects initial formation of platelet plug and to some degree factor VIII, it does not place a patient at risk of haemarthrosis (large bleeds)

A 65 year old man presented to the Emergency Department with a six-hour history of interscapular pain, urinary retention and mild bilateral leg weakness. On further questioning, he revealed that he had felt unwell for six weeks and had lost 3 kg in the past month. 

On examination he had a distended bladder, signs of motor dysfunction in both legs, decreased sensation to the level of his rib cage and reduction in vibration sense below his iliac crest. 

What is your provisional dx?

• Spinal Metastases --> spinal cord compression
  • Note: Cancers metastasising to bone = lung, prostate, breast, colon, myeloma, kidney

A 65 year old man presented to the Emergency Department with a six-hour history of interscapular pain, urinary retention and mild bilateral leg weakness. On further questioning, he revealed that he had felt unwell for six weeks and had lost 3 kg in the past month. 

On examination he had a distended bladder, signs of motor dysfunction in both legs, decreased sensation to the level of his rib cage and reduction in vibration sense below his iliac crest. 

What are your differential diagnoses?

1. Vertebral # (OP --> crush # --> retro-pulsion of fragment impinges spinal cord) 
  2. Vertebral Disk Herniation 
  3. Osteomyelitis/Abscess (UTI or other infection source spreading to spine ) 
Pott’s Disease (TB --> vertebral osteomyelitis) 
Paget’s Disease 
Spondylolisthesis (zygapophyseal joint dislocation – would likely need to be bilateral) 
Multiple myeloma (myeloma --> lytic lesion --> pathological fracture)

A 65 year old man presented to the Emergency Department with a six-hour history of interscapular pain, urinary retention and mild bilateral leg weakness. On further questioning, he revealed that he had felt unwell for six weeks and had lost 3 kg in the past month. 

On examination he had a distended bladder, signs of motor dysfunction in both legs, decreased sensation to the level of his rib cage and reduction in vibration sense below his iliac crest. 

What investigations are appropriate?

Bedside 
Urinalysis

Bloods
FBC: 
  • normochromic, normocytic anaemia and thrombocytopenia (bone marrow involvement)
  • Raised WCC (osteomyelitis)
  • CMP (↑Ca2+, paraneoplastic effect) 
  • ALP (↑in bony mets) 
  • EUC (↑ in urinary retention 2o to prostate cancer causing obstruction) 
  • LFT (mets) 
  • PSA & DRE (↑ suggests prostate cancer, >20ng/mL --> bone scan) 
Imaging 
  • MRI/CT spine (osteoblastic lesions in prostate ca) 
  • CXR (TB, malignancy) 
  • Transrectal U/S & biopsy
  • Bone scan (mets-later)

Discuss public health perspectives of PSA screening

Pros
  1. [[oc1::Detect prostate cancer early (usually is asymptomatic) ]]
  2. [[oc2::Men diagnosed with early PCa live longer c.f. more advanced ca ]]
  3. [[oc3::PCa which has spread outside of prostate is generally incurable]] 
Cons
  1. [[oc4::5% of men > 80years have prostate cancer but only <4% will die for it]]
  2. [[oc5::A/E of unnecessary treatment = erectile dysfunction, urinary incontinence]]
  3. [[oc6::By itself, PSA has too low PPV- false +ves: BPH, Prostatitis, 24 hours post ejaculation, <7d post urinary catheterisation, TURP]]

Describe the prostate

A [[oc1::glandular]] organ with a [[oc2::fibromuscular]] capsule shaped like an [[oc3::inverted pyramid]] which surrounds the [[oc4::neck of the urinary bladder]]. It contains the [[oc5::two ejaculatory ducts]] which both join with the [[oc6::proximal urethra]] to form the [[oc7::prostatic urethra]].

DRE clinical exam of prostate findings if Ca vs BPH?
Prostate gland enlargement by nodules arising from the transitional zone
Where do most cases of PCa arise from?
Peripheral part of the prostate (70% of the prostate), particularly in the posterior region, facilitating palpation during rectal examination

Signs and symptoms of BPH?

(mostly from obstruction)
Urgency
Below the prostate is the [[oc1::urethral sphincter]], and above it is the [[oc2::vesical sphincter]]. When the [[oc3::vesical sphincter]] is encroached upon, leads to leakage of urine into the [[oc4::prostatic urethra]] and an intense desire to micturate

Hesitancy
Enlarged [[oc5::median lobe]] can also compress the [[oc6::urethral orifice]] in the bladder and act like a [[oc7::flap valve]] every time the pressure (to pee) rises, leading to [[oc8::difficulty starting a stream]]

Poor stream
Once stream starts, poor stream  because the [[oc9::prostatic urethra]] is elongated, compressed and distorted  by the [[oc10::expanding medial and lateral lobes]]

DDx:
  • Other IBD - {{c21::Crohn's disease}}
  • Infectious - {{c21::Gastroenteritis (Camp., Shigella, C. Diff)}}
  • Malabsorptive - {{c21::Coeliac disease}}
  • Medications - {{c21::Pseudomembranous colitis, laxatives}}

History: 
  • [[oc1::Characterise pain and diarrhoea. 
  • Ask about extraintestinal IBD Sx (joints, eyes, skin)
  • Constitutional and infective Sx
  • PMHx, Meds, FHx, travel Hx
  • Smoking/drugs/ETOH
    • ]]
Examination:
  • [[oc5::
  • Clubbing
  • Anaemia (pallor, stomatitis, sinus tachy)
  • Abdominal palpation (tenderness, masses)
  • DRE – peri-anal disease (UC), mass, fissure, haemorrhoid, frank blood
  • Extra-intestinal examination (eyes – uveitis, joints – sacroillitis, skin – pyoderma gangrenosum, erythema nodosum
    • ]]
Bedside:
  • [[oc2::Stool MCS, OPS (ova, parasites, spores)
  • C. Diff toxin test (TcdA/TcdB)
    • ]]
Bloods:
  • [[oc3::FBC (Fe anaemia), ESR/CRP
  • LFT (liver issues, pri sclerosing cholangitis)
  • EUC/CMP (electrolyte disturbances, dehydration)
  • ANCA/ASCA (p-ANCA +ve in 70% of UC)
  • Blood cultures (sepsis)
    • ]]
Imaging:
  • [[oc4::Colonoscopy + biopsy (contraindicated with toxic megacolon)
  • AXR or CT Abdo (if suspect perforation or toxic megacolon - >6cm diameter)
    • UC - loss of haustra, granular mucosa, shortened colon
    • Crohn's - cobblestoning, "rose thorn" ulcers, colon strictures w/ rectal sparing
    ]]
Other:
  • TFT (hyperthyroid = non-bloody diarrhoea)
  • Transglutaminase Ab test + Anti-endomysial Ab (IgA type) = Coeliac disease
  • FOBT 
  • PCR (?virus)

What are the categories of complications of UC?

Intestinal (acute, chronic)

Extra-intestinal (eyes, skin, joints, haem, hepatobill, bones, dehydration, nails)
What are the acute complications of UC?

• Perforation +/- peritonitis
  • Bleeding (from erosion of an artery, rare, but life threatening)
  • Toxic megacolon +/- rupture
What are the chronic complications of UC?

• Colonic adenocarcinoma (CRC)
  • Perianal abscess
  • Fistula (more likely with Crohn's due to transmural inflammation)
  • Strictures
  • amyloidosis

rectal → +oral → +oral corticosteroids → alternatives and biologicals
]]

Alternatives:
  • {{c21::Azathioprine or 6-mercaptopurine}}
  • {{c21::Infliximab}} 
Surgery:{{c21::
  • curative, reduces risk of colon cancer
  • indicated if acute complications, severe relapses, long term dependance on steroids
  • Proctocolectomy
  • can be cured surgically, unlike Crohn's 
}}

General
  • [[oc1::nicotine]] abstinence
  • lactose intolerance - [[oc2::lactose-free diet]]
  • appropriate [[oc3::nutrion]] supplementation
  • bile acid diarrhoea - [[oc4::give ion-exchange resins to bind bile acids (eg. cholestyramine) to reduce osmotic diarhhoea (risk of steatorrhoea)]]
  • During acute episodes: [[oc5::avoid dietary fibre, consider parenteral nutrition]]

Pharmacotherapy
  • [[oc6::step up or step down therapy (weak to strong, or strong to weak meds)]]
Surgery
  • [[oc7::
  • if medical therapy fails, or complications (obstruction, fistula, stricture)
  • non-curative, last resort
  • resection of affected bowel
    • ]]
Prevention
  • [[oc8::
  • regular check ups
  • Smoking cessation
  • prophylactic Abx, 5-ASAs, etc
    • ]]

Patient presents with flank pain and dysuria.
Temp: 39oC
HR: 120 bpm
BP: 90/60
What is your diagnosis?

PDx: Septic shock, secondary to pyelonephritis
given low BP, tachycardai, fever, dysuria

DDx: 
Infectious: acute cystitis, PID
Non-infectious: renal calculi
